revision.comment: /* top */ not a proper noun; and non-restrictive [[apposition]]
revision.text:
[[File:F9F-2 VF-112 crash 1950.jpeg|thumb|Weymouth following 1950 crash of his [[F9F-2 Panther|F9F-2 VF-112]].]]'''Ralph Weymouth''' is a decorated retired [[Vice Admiral]] of the [[United States Navy]] and [[anti-nuclear]] campaigner.<ref>[http://articles.courant.com/2006-08-31/entertainment/0608310245_1_navy-cross-screening-dedicated Susan Dunne, Combat Pilot Turns Pacifist ''[[Hartford Courant]]'' August 31, 2006.]</ref>
Weymouth was born in 1917 in [[Seattle]] to Ralph Wells Weymouth and his wife Lisbeth Cunningham Sewall. He graduated in 1938 from the [[Naval academy]]. During [[World War II]] while serving as Commanding Officer of Bombing Squadron 16 (VB-16), on the [[USS Lexington (CV-2)|U.S.S. ''Lexington'']], he fought the [[Japanese Navy]] in the vicinity of the East [[Philippine Sea]] on June 20, 1944. He also served in the [[Korean War|Korea]] and [[Vietnam War]]s.
He was awarded twice [[Legion of Merit]] and four times the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]]<ref>[http://valor.militarytimes.com/recipient.php?recipientid=27160 Valor awards for Ralph Weymouth - Military Times Hall of Valor].</ref> He was also awarded [[Navy Cross]].
During Service in post-war [[Japan]], he became concerned at the effects of [[nuclear war]] on the inhabitants of [[Nagasaki]] and [[Hiroshima]] and became an opponent of [[nuclear weapon]]s, becoming more active in retirement.
He is the father of [[Tina Weymouth]], former bassist for the [[Talking Heads]], and [[architect]] [[Yann R. Weymouth]].<ref>[http://www.review.net/section/detail/no-rock-star-chitect/ Gulf Coast Business review: "No Rock Star-chitect" by Carl Cronan] August 27, 2010</ref>
